title: Cannot delegate IntoIterator for wrapper type due to blanket impl
body:
It would be convenient for wrapper types (such as `Rc` or `Arc`, but also custom wrappers) to forward `IntoIterator` implementations on references. Assuming the type derefs to some inner type, something like:
```rust
impl<'a, T> IntoIterator for &'a Wrapper<T>
where
    &'a T: IntoIterator,
{
    type Item = <T as IntoIterator>::Item;
    type IntoIter = <T as IntoIterator>::IntoIter;
    fn into_iter(self) -> Self::IntoIter {
        (**self).into_iter()
    }
}
```

Unfortunately, this does not work today due to the following `impl` on `IntoIterator`:
```rust
impl<I> IntoIterator for I 
where
    I: Iterator, 
  type Item = <I as Iterator>::Item;
  type IntoIter = I;
```

Specifically, as I understand it, the compiler now applies the `I: Iterator` bound to our impl above, and gives lots of warnings of the form
```text
error[E0277]: the trait bound `T: std::iter::Iterator` is not satisfied
   --> src/types/mod.rs:120:5
    |
120 |     type IntoIter = <T as IntoIterator>::IntoIter;
    |     ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ `T` is not an iterator; maybe try calling `.iter()` or a similar method
    |
    = help: the trait `std::iter::Iterator` is not implemented for `T`
    = help: consider adding a `where T: std::iter::Iterator` bound
    = note: required because of the requirements on the impl of `std::iter::IntoIterator` for `T`
```

I'm not entirely sure that there exists a feasible workaround for this, but figured I'd flag it nonetheless.
